title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: As we reached the Broomhill road we met Mrs. Stewart of Greenknowe, her daughter Mary, and Lily Easton, the youngest daughter of the farmer of Blinkbonny Mains—one of the largest farms in the parish. The farmhouse was an old mansion-house, and was situated about two miles to the north-east of the village.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: I took a walk up to the Knowe here to gather fir-taps for my mother to kin'le the fire wi'; she says it's owre warm to keep it in a' nicht, an' the fir-taps has rozet (rosin) in them, an' they're grand for kin'lin' a fire after they're dried; this is a pockfu' 0' them; an' good-bye, sir. I wad like to be at the Broomhill road afore Miss Stewart passes. She kens me, an' aye speaks awfu' nice to me."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " I'll go with you," said Mr. M'Nab, glad to have such an unexpected chance of meeting Miss Stewart; and, as they had reached the Broomhill road before she was at the Knowe gate, Jamie pointed out the " Fillies' Bridge," the " dookin' pool at the crook 0' the den," and other objects of interest. He seized his bonnet as Miss Stewart approached, and pulled his head with it so as to make a very low bow, all the time grinning from ear to ear; and, after answering her inquiries about the little ones, he made a low bow to each of them and was off, still grinning with delight.

snippet: John was confounded, and disappointed, and angry ; he turned quickly on his heel, strode wrathfully to the top of Nancie's Knowe, along the Broomhill road, and up and down. His thoughts were not charitable, not at all in keeping with either his dress or profession.

snippet: Accordingly Willie went to the church of his fathers, the Auld Licht Antiburgher Church of Broomhill, and the first thing he heard was the precentor reading that " the prayrers of this congregation are requested for a member in sore trouble, and for his afflicted famdy."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition

snippet: On a fine morning in the autumn of 1836, Strachan Gemmell, with a dingy shepherd's plaid round his neck and a staff in his hand, was striding along the Broomhill road, followed at a short distance by Big Murray, who carried a large smoothing-iron, better known as a " tailor's goose," under the one arm, and a piece of smooth tapered wood about a yard in length, called a lap-board or " la'brod," under the other.
